_prev_prog_2.Description: Safety and Environmental Manual, ANSI K61.1, 1989 and Rules and Regulations of Indiana State Chemist

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY for Harvest Land Co-op., Dunreith Ag Center



1. The Facility Policy



The owners, management, and employees of Harvest Land, are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information



This facility is a retail farm supply center. We handle a variety of farm supplies, including pesticides and fertilizers. We are distributors of Anhydrous Ammonia, a product regulated by U.S. E.P.A. We receive Anhydrous Ammonia by truck and store on site in two (2) 30,000 gallon storage tanks and distribute to our customers in (18) eighteen 1,000 gallon nurse tanks, (10) ten 1,500 galon nurse tanks and (1) one 2000 gallon urse tank. This gives our facility a maximum storage capacity of 450,000 pounds of Anhydrous Ammonia. Our customers then use the nurse tanks in applying the fertilizer to the soil.



3. The Accident Release Prevention Program



The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling Of Anhydrous Ammonia". Additional information contained in our Safety and Environmental Manual and the Rules and Regulations or the Indiana State Chemist concerning Anhydrous Ammonia are also utilized.



4. The Five-year Accident History 



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility or to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite injuries, property damage, or environmental damage.



5. The Emergency Re

sponse Program



This facility has a written emergency response plan, in accordance with OSHA standards 29 CFR 1910.38, and 29 CFR 1910.120. We have also provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA). Our emergency response plan is reviewed and updated annually or when changes are made which require updating.



6. Planned Changes To Improve Safety



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the operating conditions of Anhydrous Ammonia equipment. As new rules, regulations or operating procedures are introduced they are evaluated and our procedures are updated to reflect the changes.



7.  Additional Information:

This 5-year resubmission was delayed because of a typographic error in the 2004 submission which required the help of the RMP Reporting Center to correct to allow the correct dates to be entered for this submission.  Mr. Osci Miller assisted in accomplishing the corrections to allow this submission to be completed.
